#Text=Nicholas Bownde
#Text=Nicholas Bownde , Bownd or Bound ( died 1613 ) was an English clergyman , known for his Christian Sabbatarian writings .
#Text=Life
#Text=He was son of Robert Bownde ( Bound ) , M.D. , physician to the Duke of Norfolk .
#Text=He was educated at Peterhouse , Cambridge , where he graduated B.A. in 1572 , was elected a fellow later that year , and graduated M.A. in 1575 . [ 1 ]
#Text=On 3 September 1585 he was instituted to the rectory of Norton , Suffolk , a living in the gift of his college . He was created D.D. at Cambridge in 1594 .
#Text=In 1611 Bownde became minister of the church of St. Andrew the Apostle at Norwich , and he was buried there on 26 December 1613 .
#Text=He married the widow of John More , the ' apostle of Norwich . ' His sister Anne married John Dod and his widowed mother married as her second husband Richard Greenham .
#Text=Works
#Text=In 1595 Bownde published the first edition of his treatise on Sabbath .

#Text=In it he maintained that the seventh part of our time ought to be devoted to the service of God ; that Christians are bound to rest on the first day of the week [ 2 ] as much as the Jews were on Mosaical Sabbath .

#Text=He contended that Sabbath was profaned by interludes , May-games , morris dances , shooting , bowling , and similar sports ; and he would not allow any feasting on that day , though an exception was made in favour of ' noblemen and great personages ' . [ 3 ]
#Text=The observance of the Lord 's Day became a question between the high-church party and the puritans , an early disagreement on doctrine .
#Text=The Sabbatarian question was noticed by the bishops , and they cited several ministers before the ecclesiastical courts for preaching it .
#Text=But the strict Sabbatarian doctrine spread .
#Text=His works are :
#Text=' Three godly and fruitfull Sermons , declaring how we may be saved in the day of Judgement . . . .
#Text=Preached and written by M. John More , late Preacher in the Citie of Norwitch .
#Text=And now first published by M. Nicholas Bound , whereto he hath adjoined of his owne , A Sermon of Comfort for the Afflicted ; and a short treatise of a contented mind , ' Cambridge , 1594 .
#Text='
#Text=The Doctrine of the Sabbath , plainely layde forth , and soundly proued by testimonies both of holy Scripture , and also of olde and new ecclesiastical writers . . . .
#Text=Together with the sundry abuses of our time in both these kindes , and how they ought to bee reformed , ' London , 1595 .
#Text=Dedicated to Robert Devereux , 2nd Earl of Essex .
#Text=This work was attacked by Thomas Rogers in 1599 . [ 4 ]
#Text=Reprinted , with additions , under the title of ' Sabbathvm veteris et novi Testamenti : or the true doctrine of the Sabbath . . . , ' London , 1606 .
#Text=' Medicines for the Plagve : that is , Godly and fruitfull Sermons vpon part of the twentieth Psalme . . . more particularly applied to this late visitation of the Plague , ' London , 1604 .
#Text='
#Text=The Holy Exercise of Fasting .
#Text=Described largely and plainly out of the word of God . ...
#Text=In certaine Homilies or Sermons . . . , ' Cambridge , 1604 .
#Text=Dedicated to John Jegon , bishop of Norwich .
#Text='
#Text=The Vnbeliefe of St. Thomas the Apostle , laid open for the comfort of all that desire to beleeue . . . , ' London , 1608 , reprinted , London , 1817 .
#Text=A Treatise ful of Consolation for all that are afflicted in minde or bodie or otherwise ... , Cambridge , 1608 ; reprinted , London , 1817 .
#Text=The reprints of this and the preceding work were edited by G. W. Marriot .

#Text=Bownde has a Latin ode before Peter Baro 's Prælectiones in Ionam , 1579 ; and he edited John More 's Table from the Beginning of the World to this Day . Wherein is declared in what yeere of the World everything was done , Cambridge , 1593 .
